articles.title: Überschall-Jet mit Mach 1,7 - Schon 130 Bestellungen für die Erbin der Concorde
articles.image_title: ILLUSTRATION SHOWS: XB-1 is an important milestone towards the development of Boom's commercial airliner, Overture, pictured here. ... STORY: Boom Supersonic, the aerospace company building the world's fastest airliner, in Denver on Wednesday (7 Oct), unveiled its supersonic demonstrator, XB-1, history's first independently developed supersonic jet. To design and build XB-1, Boom recruited a team of experts from around the industry, forged relationships with key suppliers, and built a strong safety culture. XB-1 is slated to fly for the first time in 2021 and will undergo a 100% carbon-neutral flight test program. Boom's innovations include developing one of the highest-efficiency civil supersonic engine intakes ever tested, demonstrating Boom's ability to deliver a breakthrough in propulsive efficiency for Overture. "Boom continues to make progress towards our founding mission—making the world dramatically more accessible," said Blake Scholl, Boom founder and CEO. "XB-1 is an important milestone towards the development of our commercial airliner, Overture, making sustainable supersonic flight mainstream and fostering human connection." Boom's XB-1 virtual rollout highlighted some of XB-1's notable features including: Shape: XB-1's 71-foot-long fuselage has been optimally shaped for high-speed aerodynamic efficiency. Materials: The carbon-composite airframe maintains its strength and rigidity, even under the high temperatures and stresses of supersonic flight. Wing: The delta wing balances low-speed stability at takeoff and landing with high-speed efficiency. Propulsion: Three J85-15 engines, designed by General Electric, provide more than 12,000 pounds of thrust, allowing XB-1 to fly at breakthrough supersonic speeds. Cockpit ergonomics: Guidance and feedback from XB-1's test pilots played a key role in cockpit design, which was the product of hundreds of hours of human factors and usability testing...
articles.author: Stefan Beutelsbacher

articles.title: So kippte der Goldstandard und führte zur „Nixon-Geldklemme“
articles.image_title: Mit ablehnender Gestik gibt ein Bankangestellter einem Kunden zu verstehen, dass die Bank keine Devisen, seien es auch Dollars, annimmt, aufgenommen am 5. Mai 1971 in Frankfurt am Main. Die Geschäftsbanken und die Sparkassen der Bundesrepublik Deutschland haben am 5.5.1971 den Ankauf jeglicher Devisen auf den Gegenwert von 5000 D-Mark beschränkt. Dollarbeträge wurden teilweise ganz abgelehnt. Das Bundeskabinett will am 8.5.1971 über den DM-Wechselkurs entscheiden. Der Zentralbankrat fasste am 5.5.1971 keine kreditpolitischen Beschlüsse.
articles.author: Antonia Kleikamp
